occurrences.line_text: And saw his carriage past that perill well,
And comely carriage of her count'nance trim,
As comely carriage, entertainement kynde,
Whose semblance she did carrie vnder feigned hew.
Timely to ioy, and carrie comely cheare.
It carried, that I scarse in darkesome place
So fast he carried her with carefull paine,
Vpon his shoulders carried him perforse
Carried her forward with her first intent:
Carried away with wings of speedy feare.
The carkas with the streame was carried downe,
And with them carried, to be fostered;
Perforce her carried, where euer he thought best.
And carried her beyond all ieopardy,
What wonder then, if she were likewise carried?
His corps was carried downe along the Lee,
Or being carried farre from forraine lands.
Carried with wings of feare, like fowle aghast,
An hart, not carried with too curious eyes,
Thence they him carried to a Castle neare,
Whom Calidore thus carried on his chine,
And being carried with his force forthright,
And carried captiue by those theeues away;
Great cause, that carries thee so swift and light.
And carries into smoake with rage and horror great.
That still for carrion carcases doth craue:
Why should not that dead carrion satisfie
And hauing scruzd out of his carrion corse
Hauing his carrion corse quite sencelesse left,
Or it approue vpon his carrion corse.
That hunting after game hath carrion found,
There they him left a carrion outcast;
Vnto some carrion offered to his sight,
Came dauncing forth, and ioyous carrols song:
And to her watry chamber swiftly carry him.
As fast as feete could carry them away;
Which carry colours faire, that feeble eies misdeeme.
That for these Carles to carry much more comely were?
On euery side of his embatteld cart,
An Altare, caru'd with cunning imagery,
That I can carue with this inchaunted brond
The caruer Holme, the Maple seeldom inward sound.
Which euer after in most wretched case,
To wayle his woefull case she would not stay,
Whose case when as the carefull Dwarfe had tould,
Was firmest fixt in mine extremest case,
In case he could that monstrous beast destroy,
Wherewith she sighed soft, as if his case she rewd.
In case he haue no Ladie, nor no loue,
How him in deadly case their Lady fownd,
My Ladies loue, in such a desperate case,
That present were to testifie the case.
The dreadfull stroke in case it had arriued,
Whilst thus the case in doubtfull ballance hong,
To deeme this doutfull case, for which they all co[n]tended.
And voide his course: at which so suddain case
That all the gods did mone her miserable case.
Full of sad anguish, and in heauy case:
She knew him not, but pittied much his case,
But wondred much at his so selcouth case,
The euill case in which those Ladies lay;
He cald to him aloud, his case to rew,
An hard mishap and disauentrous case
And diuersly conferred of their case,
In case his burning lust should breake into excesse.
There vnto him betid a disauentrous case.
So feelingly her case she did complaine,
She gan afresh thus to renew her wretched case.
In better case, ne keepes his course more right,
Reioyced at his miserable case,
That euer in this wretched case ye were?
With which in case thou canst him not inuade,
In case she might finde fauour in his eye,
Promist, if she would free him from that case,
With fayned colours shading a true case:
The tryall of a great and weightie case,
Who priuie was, and partie in the case:
Sith ye thus farre haue tendred my poore case,
Hard is the case, the which ye doe complaine;
Such was Irenas countenance, such her case,
To whom he answerd thus; My haplesse case
His mightie hart their mournefull case can rew,
That was a straunger to her wretched case;
Too greatly grieue at any his vnlucky case.
With thinking to what case her name should now be brought.
Thus whilest he was in this distressed case,
Nathelesse the Knight now in so needy case,
And when he had deuized of her case,
To seeke some comfort in that sorie case.
The which was fall'n into this feeble case,
That with the ruth of her so wretched case,
Much did the Crauen seeme to mone his case,
But plainely gan to him declare the case
Throughout the world, in this vncomely case,
Ensample take of Mirabellaes case,
He like a dog was led in captiue case,
So inward shame of her vncomely case
Yet could not remedie her wretched case;
Did much the more augment, and made most vgly cases.
In cases like, which when at last she saw,
Who swelling sayles in Caspian sea doth crosse,
(As wonts the Tartar by the Caspian lake,
Whilst they were young, Cassibalane their Eme
Aboue the shynie Cassiopeias chaire,
As messenger of Morpheus on them cast
Of swarming Bees, did cast him in a swowne:
Cast a blacke stole, most like to seeme for Vna fit.
He cast about, and searcht his balefull bookes againe.
One day in doubt I cast for to compare,
What not by right, she cast to win by guile,
And that dread Lyons looke her cast in deadly hew.
Into new woes vnweeting I was cast,
At last the Paynim chaunst to cast his eye,
Of all attonce he cast auengd to bee,
Some cursed vengeance on his sonne to cast:
Yet first he cast by treatie, and by traynes,
And cast her colours dyed deepe in graine,
Would haue cast downe, and trod in durtie myre,
Her golden cup she cast vnto the ground,
From that day forth I cast in carefull mind,
Still as he fled, his eye was backward cast,
She cast to bring him, where he chearen might,
With lookes full lowly cast, and gate full slow,
To Vna back he cast him to retire;
He cast to suffer him no more respire,
He cast at once him to auenge for all,
That I may cast to compasse your reliefe,
And cast to seeke him forth through daunger and great dreed.
One that to bountie neuer cast his mind,
Eftsoones to court he cast t'auaunce his first degree.
From that day forth he cast for to vphold
Then him to ground he cast, and rudely hayld,
I cast to pay, that I so dearely bought;
And soone his dreadfull blade about he cast,
He cast him downe to ground, and all along
Hauing his warlike weapons cast behind,
He cast betwene to ward the bitter stound:
Who Guyons shield cast euer him before,
And through his nimble sleight did vnder him down cast.
Did not once moue, nor vpward cast his eye,
Doth blow them quite away, and in the Ocean cast.
Ouer the which was cast a wandring vine,
Vnto the ground she cast her modest eye,
Which he espying, cast her to restraine
Gan heap huge strokes on him, as ere he downe was cast.
Therefore to ground he would him cast no more,
Hedlong her selfe did cast into that lake;
The cup to ground did violently cast,
Old Glauce cast, to cure this Ladies griefe:
And cast t'auenge him of that fowle despight,
She cast to comfort him with busie paine:
For thy, she thither cast her course t'apply,
But she to none of them her loue did cast,
Ne euer cast his mind to couet prayse,
And cast to loue her in his brutish mind;
To leaue that desert mansion, she cast
And crost the nearest way, by which he cast
He cast to punish for his hainous fault;
And after cast him vp, vpon the shore;
With harder meanes he cast her to subdew,
I found her golden girdle cast astray,
And cast himselfe on ground her fast besyde:
But when againe he backward cast his eye,
Ten thousand wayes he cast in his confused thought.
To giust with that braue straunger knight a cast,
For hauing filcht her bels, her vp he cast
Tho as she backward cast her busie eye,
She cast to vse, both fit for hard emprize;
She cast her eies, to see what was become
Cast how to salue, that both the custome showne
That hauing cast him in a foolish trance,
And cast t'auenge his friends indignity.
To stumble, that his rider nigh he cast;
And cast t'auenge the shame doen to his freend:
He gan to cast how to appease the same,
To whom she did her liking lightly cast,
Cast into sundry shapes by wondrous skill,
Then did he cast to steale her thence away,
Not so to leaue her, nor away to cast,
Did cast about by sleight the truth thereout to straine.
Either the other from his steede to cast;
Ouer the Castle wall adowne her cast,
And with their troupes did far a sunder cast:
Gan cast a secret liking to this captiue straunge.
Therefore I cast, how I may him vnbind,
And gan thenceforth to cast affection,
Did cast for to allure, into her trap to fall.
She gan to cast in her misdoubtfull mynde
And then she in her wrathfull will did cast,
The other ouer side the Bridge she cast
And euer round about he cast his looke.
But he then stones at it so long did cast,
And fowle blasphemous speaches forth did cast,
And cast his shield about, to be in readie plight.
And twixt him and the blow his shield did cast,
And stones did cast, yet he for nought would swerue
That him vpon the ground he groueling cast;
Cast to requite, and with a slender dart,
And twixt them twaine with equall care to cast,
He cast to keepe him selfe so safely as he may.
Had left that couple, nere their vtmost cast.
Vpon a day he cast abrode to wend,
That wanting breath, him downe to ground he cast;
She saw now left, she cast to leaue the place,
Reuiued was, and sad dispaire away did cast.
She on her way cast forward to proceede,
As when a cast of Faulcons make their flight
The end whereof Ile keepe vntill another cast.
In that same quest which Fortune on him cast,
That worldly chaunces doe amongst them cast,
And in his mind with better reason cast,
Which well auizing, streight she gan to cast
Did cast to ground, whilest none was them to rew;
Did cast his shield atweene, and therewithall
Forth ryding vnderneath the castell wall,
Vnto a Castell, lodged there to bee,
By all meanes to maintaine that castels ancient rights.
In which were many towres and castels set,
Then casting vp a deadly looke, full low,
But casting wrongs and all reuenge behind,
And casting from her that enchaunted lance,
By casting secret flakes of lustfull fire
Him to his castle brought with hastie forse,
He forst to castle strong to take their flight,
Nigh to a castle builded strong and hie:
He marched forth towards that castle wall;
That all the castle quaked from the ground,
Or as a Castle reared high and round,
Into the Castle entred forcibly,
Did in that castle afterwards abide,
Be wonne, to spoyle the Castle of his health?
Vnto the watchman on the castle wall;
Till that at last they to a Castle came,
Whenas they spide a goodly castle, plast
And wind his horne vnder the castle wall,
And with long siege vs in this castle hould:
Vnto the castle gate they come againe,
And brought them vp into her castle hall;
Of that faire Castle to affoord them vew;
First she them led vp to the Castle wall,
That castle to assaile on euery side,
Seuen of the same against the Castle gate,
Against that Castle restlesse siege did lay,
And led him to the Castle by the beaten way.
A stately Castle farre away she spyde,
That Castle was most goodly edifyde,
Within this castle wall a Ladie faire,
And stately port of Castle Ioyeous,
(For so that Castle hight by commune name)
And the great Castle smite so sore with all,
Which if ye please, to yonder castle turne your gate.
Forth marched to a Castle them before,
Into that Castle (as that Squire does tell.)
And to the Castle gate approcht in quiet wise.
Came to that Castle, and with earnest mone,
And to them calling from the castle wall,
And stoutly came vnto the Castle gate;
Till to his castle they approched neare.
Then gan they ransacke that same Castle strong,
There reared was a castle faire and strong,
Before that Castle was an open plaine,
That all the castle ringed with the clap.
Does race her castle quight.
It will be at the Castle of the strond;
That done, vnto the Castle he did wend,
Eftsoones his Page drew to the Castle gate,
Vppon the Castle wall, and when she saw
And powred forth ouer the Castle wall,
Ouer the Castle wall adowne her cast,
And lastly all that Castle quite he raced,
Departed from the Castle of the strond,
And in her necke a Castle huge had made,
That Castle was the strength of all that state,
Both goodly Castle, and both goodly Towne,
To him he hath, before this Castle greene,
But ryding streight vnder the Castle wall,
And thence vnto the castle marched right,
Then all the rest which in that Castle were,
Thenceforth into that Castle he her led,
Vnto the Castle, which they conquerd had.
He sternely marcht before the Castle gate,
Which when the Lady from the Castle saw,
Hard by a streight there stands a castle strong,
This Castle, is by name Briana hight.
Which to prouide, she hath this Castle dight,
Toward the Castle, where if need constraine,
With that the rest, the which the Castle kept,
There where she stood vppon the Castle wall,
So all returning to the Castle glad,
She freely gaue that Castle for his paine,
Thence they him carried to a Castle neare,
Vnto the Castle where they had decreed.
There of the Knight, the which that Castle ought,
And with his Lady to the Castle rid,
That doth thus strongly ward the Castle of the ford.
Vnto the Castle of Belgard her brought,
Castles surprizd, great cities sackt and brent:
To vew her castles other wondrous frame.
On th'other side, th'assieged Castles ward
Against that Castles Lord they gan conspire,
Great cities ransackt, and strong castles rast,
Which when his Ladie from the castles hight
With faire vermilion or pure Castory.
And shooting in the earth, casts vp a mount of clay.
Casts off his ragged skin and freshly doth him dight.
To catch her, newly offred to his eie:
But if I catch him in this company,
He may them catch, vnable to gainestriue,
Arthur and Artegall catch Guyle
Fit to catch hold of all that he could weld,
The birds to catch, or fishes to beguyle:
Disperseth them to catch his choysest pray;
To catchen hold of that long chaine, thereby
But suddaine catching hold, did her dismay
Who by her cleanly garment catching hold,
And catching vp in hast his three square shield,
And catching hold of her vngratious tong,
And of him catching hold him strongly stayd
And catching hold of him, as downe he lent,
And on him catching hold, gan loud to crie
And catching hold of this Sea-beaten chest,
And catching her fast by her ragged weed,
But catching vp in hand a ragged stone,
And catching vp his arms streight to the noise forth past.
Whom catching greedily for great desire,
A shepheard, when Mnemosyne he catcht:
And some of cats, that wrawling still did cry,
And for her sake her cattell fed a while,
The painefull plough, or cattell for to breed,
There placed was a caudron wide and tall,
So long as any thing it in the caudron got.
About the Caudron many Cookes accoyld,
And brasen Caudrons thou shalt rombling heare,
And eke an hundred brasen caudrons bright,
At length it brought them to a hollow caue,
And euer since hath kept in darksome caue,
And would haue backe retyred to her caue,
Where was a Caue ywrought by wondrous art,
His dwelling has, low in an hollow caue,
That darkesome caue they enter, where they find
As fearefull fowle, that long in secret caue
Like an huge caue, hewne out of rocky clift,
Like as a fire, the which in hollow caue
It is an hideous hollow caue (they say)
Like as a Lyon, that in drowsie caue
And in a rocky caue as wight forlorne,
In a strong rocky Caue, which is they say,
Eftsoones out of her hidden caue she cald
Therein is eaten out an hollow caue,
That at the last he found a caue with entrance small.
Vnto his caue farre from all peoples hearing,
Came to the caue, and rolling thence the stone,
And eke his caue, in which they both were bond:
Into a caue from companie exilde,
The cry whereof entring the hollow caue,
He came vnto his caue, and there did vew
When to the Caue they came, they found it fast:
Vnto the caue gan preasse, nought hauing dout
And fild her hidden caues with stormie yre,
And lurkt in rocks and caues long vnespide.
Lurking in rockes and caues farre vnder ground,
Out of the rockes and caues adioyning nye,
Which in th'earthes hollow caues hath long bin hid,
Mongst rocks and caues, where she enrold doth lie
Through hollow caues, that no man mote discouer
Into their caues, their heads from death to hide,
The fish that once was caught, new bait will hardly bite.
Woe neuer wants, where euery cause is caught,
Tho vp he caught him twixt his puissant hands,
Rather then of the tyrant to be caught:
She caught in hand an huge great yron mace,
Me seely wretch she so at vauntage caught,
An headlesse heape, him vnawares there caught,
Caught hold on me, and thought my steps to stay,
And there was caught to her confusion.
She quickly caught her sword, & shield about her bound.
Out of her fist the wicked weapon caught:
Caught her thus loosely wandring here and there,
Caught like the bird, which gazing still on others stands.
Whom they before in diuerse spoyles had caught:
That causd her shed so many a bitter teare,
Eftsoones she causd him vp to be conuayd,
And in his costly Bath causd to bee site:
Hath lately caus'd to be proclaim'd each where
And pacifie the strife, which causd so deadly smart.
Causd all her people to surcease from fight,
Causd his pauilion to be richly pight
She causd to be attacht, and forthwith led
Amongst the which she causd his warlike armes
And causd him those vncomely weedes vndight;
Whom she had causd be kept as prisonere,
There him he causd to kneele, and made to sweare
And causde great sackes with endlesse riches fraught,
Causde me be called to accompt therefore,
Where cause is none, but to your rest depart.
For present cause was none of dread her to dismay.
Good cause of mine excuse; that mote ye please
Making obeyssance, did the cause declare,
And wept, that cause of weeping none he had,
His cause in combat the next day to try:
Cause of my new griefe, cause of my new ioy,
Cause of my new griefe, cause of my new ioy,
And to him brought the shield, the cause of enmitie.
And the old cause of my continued paine
Good cause he had to hasten thence away;
The hidden cause of their captiuitie,
To weet the cause, his weake steps gouerning,
The cause was this: one day when Phoebe fayre
To tempt the cause it selfe for to bewray;
This is my cause of griefe, more great, then may be told.
Certes, Madame, ye haue great cause of plaint,
That stoutest heart, I weene, could cause to quake.
The course of heauenly cause, or vnderstand
Me hither sent, for cause to me vnghest,
The secret cause of his perplexitie:
And giues not rather cause it to forsake?
But yet the cause and root of all his ill,
What end (quoth she) should cause vs take such paine,
Who did her cause into thy hand commit,
Abet that virgins cause disconsolate,
For truth is strong, her rightfull cause to plead,
And tell the cause of your conceiued paine.
Great cause, I weene, you guided, or some vncouth chaunce.
Reserue her cause to her eternall doome,
Whiles cause not well conceiued ye mistake.
That more to mighty ha[n]ds, the[n] rightfull cause doth trust.
And were there rightfull cause of difference,
Dismay with feare, or cause one foot to flie,
Which was the cause, when earst that horne I heard,
Ne euer thing could cause vs disagree:
For when the cause of that outrageous deede
Great cause, that carries thee so swift and light.
Occasion to wrath, and cause of strife;
Woe neuer wants, where euery cause is caught,
Of curtesie to me the cause a read,
That might to her moue cause of meriment:
And cause of death betweene two doughtie knights doe breed.
To couet more, then I haue cause to vse?
When cause requird, but neuer out of time;
What euer be the cause, it sure beseemes you ill.
The cause to weet, and fault to remedy;
For she had cause to busie them withall;
The cause of their dissention and outrageous yre.
And proue his cause. With that her mortall speare
Here haue I cause, in men iust blame to find,
Defending Ladies cause, and Orphans right,
The cause some say is this: A litle while
Or other mightie cause vs two did hither send.
Doth course of naturall cause farre exceed,
To cloke the cause, that hath it selfe bewrayd?
And shortly asked her, what cause her brought
Iust cause of dread, that makes ye doubt so sore?
Gan them informe the cause, why that same dore
The cause, why Satyrane and Paridell
That is the cause, why neuer any knight
As countries cause, and commune foes disdayne.
Or hast thou, Lord, of good mens cause no heed?
And said; Sir knight, your cause is nothing lesse,
The golden Apple, cause of all their wrong,
And iustifie my cause on yonder knight.
And rather die then Ladies cause release.
Drew nigh, to weete the cause of their debate:
First he desir'd their cause of strife to see:
That doth ill cause or euill end enure:
Her cause of comming she to tell began.
The cause of both, of both their minds depends;
The cause and end thereof: but all in vaine;
Great cause of sorrow certes Sir ye haue:
The cause of that his sorrowfull constraint;
His sorrowes cause to be of her despis'd.
With forged cause them falsely to defame;
Of whom he gan enquire his cause of dread;
But cause of feare sure had she none at all
Cause of their discord, and so fell debate,
Mongst which the cause of their so cruell heat
Or did misdoubt some ill, whose cause did not appeare.
The cause why she was couered with a vele,
As euery one had cause of good or ill.
And vnderstood the cause of all her care
The secret cause and nature of his teene,
And for what cause; the truth discouer plaine.
But would some rightfull cause pretend, though rightly nought.
To sit in his owne seate, his cause to end,
And for no cause, but as I shall you shew.
But if ye please, that I your cause decide,
The cause of their array, and truce for to desire.
Till he had questioned the cause of their dissent.
To weete the cause of their assemblaunce wide.
Did aske, what cause brought that man to decay,
The cause, they say, of this her cruell hate,
To heare the piteous beast pleading her plaintiffe cause.
The cause of her conceiued maladie,
The certaine cause of Artegals detaine;
To lodge with him that night, vnles good cause empeach.
And for what cause so great mischieuous smart
For his departure, her new cause of griefe;
But either others cause to maintaine mutually.
And for what cause they chased so that Mayd.
And for what cause pursu'd of them attone.
To th'hearing of that former cause in hand,
